title: Replicating animal intelligence in 2025.en
content:
Question:
If the current tech is too weak to simulate a human behavior, what animal are there we can fully replicate it's intelligence?
1. Simple invertebrates – full replication is almost achievable today

Animal
Neurons
Current replication status
Notes

C. elegans (nematode worm)
302
✅ Full behavior replication in lab simulations
Connectome fully mapped. Neural dynamics simulated in software; all motor/reflex behaviors reproducible.

Fruit fly (Drosophila larva)
~10,000
⚠️ Partial replication
Reflexes and simple motor patterns replicated. Adult fly: ~100,000 neurons → only simple behaviors reproducible.

Scale: 10²–10⁵ neurons
Tech: Standard neural simulation software, no nanotech required
Timeline to full adult fly replication: 5–10 years with current connectome mapping projects and computational power.

2. Insects with moderate complexity – partial replication

Animal
Neurons
Status
Notes

Ants/Bees
250,000 – 1,000,000
⚠️ Partial replication
Foraging, pathfinding, and swarm behaviors replicated in robots and simulations. Full neural detail not captured.

Moths
~200,000
⚠️ Partial
Navigation and evasive flight partially replicated using robotics & sensors.

Scale: 10⁵–10⁶ neurons
Tech: Robotics + AI + partial neural emulation; nanotech sensors not required yet
Years until full neural replication: 15–30 years (assuming advances in connectomics, brain-wide imaging, and computational modeling).

3. Small vertebrates – gross behavior only

Animal
Neurons
Status
Notes

Zebrafish
~100,000 – 1,000,000
⚠️ Partial
Swimming patterns, simple learning, and reflexes replicated in labs. Full perception/emotion unavailable.

Rodents (mouse)
~71 million
⚠️ Limited
Maze navigation, basic decision-making replicable in AI models. Complex social/learning behavior not fully replicable.

Frogs
~16 million
⚠️ Limited
Motor reflexes can be simulated; adaptive behavior partially understood.

Scale: 10⁶–10⁸ neurons
Tech: High-resolution imaging, optogenetics, AI simulations. Nanotech-based neuron-level reading/manipulation is under research.
Years until full behavioral replication: 50+ years realistically, unless nanotech and high-dimensional neural recording advance faster.

4. Complex mammals – full replication currently impossible

Animal
Neurons
Status
Notes

Dogs
~500 million
❌ Impossible
Can replicate isolated tasks (pattern recognition, trained behaviors) with AI and robotics. Full cognition/emotion inaccessible.

Monkeys
6–7 billion
❌ Impossible
Partial behavior studies possible in labs; full replication would require mapping entire brain and sensory system.

Humans
~86 billion
❌ Impossible
Truly emergent behavior, consciousness, memory, and creativity cannot yet be replicated.

Scale: 10⁸–10¹¹ neurons
Tech: Hypothetical nanotech capable of real-time neuron reading/writing; quantum computation may accelerate high-dimensional simulation.
Years until even partial “full behavior replication”: 100+ years, likely only achievable with advanced nanotech and extremely high-dimensional computing.

5. Technology factors and requirements

Factor
Current capability
Future potential

Neural mapping
Electron microscopy, optogenetics, connectomics (partial)
Nanobots to read every synapse in vivo (~2040–2060)

Computation
Supercomputers, cloud clusters (~10¹⁵ FLOPS)
Exascale (~10¹⁸ FLOPS) for mammalian brains; zettascale (~10²¹ FLOPS) for humans

Nano-sensors / actuators
Research stage
Could allow real-time neuron-level replication and closed-loop simulation of complex animals

Storage
1–10 TB for worm/fruit fly neural data
~100 PB for human-scale connectome + dynamics

6. Key insights

We can fully replicate simple invertebrates today — C. elegans is essentially “solved.”

For moderate insects, full neural replication is feasible in 15–30 years with current neuroscience and AI trends.

Small vertebrates may be partially replicable by mid-century.

Complex mammals and humans are orders of magnitude beyond current tech; full replication likely requires nanotech, extreme computational resources, and ultra high-dimensional simulation — potentially a century away.

Emergent behaviors scale nonlinearly: doubling neurons multiplies complexity exponentially, not linearly.

title: Replicating animal intelligence in 2025.uz
content:
Savol:
Agar inson intellekti hozirgi texnologik resurslar bilan taqlid qilish qiyin bo‘lsa, biz hozir qaysi hayvon aqlini haqiqatan ham takrorlay olamiz?
1. Oddiy umurtqasizlar – to‘liq takrorlash bugun deyarli erishilgan

Hayvon
Neyronlar
Hozirgi takrorlash holati
Izohlar

C. elegans (nematod qurti)
302
✅ To‘liq xatti-harakatlar laboratoriya simulyatsiyalarida takrorlangan
Connectome to‘liq xaritalangan. Neyron dinamikasi dasturiy ta’minotda simulyatsiya qilingan; barcha motor/refleks xatti-harakatlari takrorlanadigan.

Frukt pashshasi (Drosophila lichinkasi)
~10,000
⚠️ Qisman takrorlash
Reflekslar va oddiy motor naqshlari takrorlangan. Kattalar pashshasi: ~100,000 neyron → faqat oddiy xatti-harakatlar takrorlanadigan.

Miqyos: 10²–10⁵ neyron
Texnologiya: Standart neyron simulyatsiya dasturlari, nanotexnologiya talab qilinmaydi
Kattalar pashshasini to‘liq takrorlash muddati: 5–10 yil, hozirgi connectome xaritalash loyihalari va hisoblash quvvati bilan.
2. O‘rtacha murakkablikdagi hasharotlar – qisman takrorlash

Hayvon
Neyronlar
Holati
Izohlar

Chumolilar/Ari
250,000 – 1,000,000
⚠️ Qisman takrorlash
Ov qilish, yo‘l topish va to‘da xatti-harakatlari robotlar va simulyatsiyalarda takrorlangan. To‘liq neyron tafsilotlari qamrab olinmagan.

Kuya
~200,000
⚠️ Qisman
Navigatsiya va qochish parvozi qisman robototexnika va sensorlar yordamida takrorlangan.

Miqyos: 10⁵–10⁶ neyron
Texnologiya: Robototexnika + AI + qisman neyron emulyatsiyasi; nanotexnologiya sensorlari hali talab qilinmaydi
To‘liq neyron takrorlashgacha yillar: 15–30 yil (connectomics, miya bo‘ylab tasvirlash va hisoblash modellashtirishdagi yutuqlarni hisobga olgan holda).
3. Kichik umurtqali hayvonlar – faqat umumiy xatti-harakatlar

Hayvon
Neyronlar
Holati
Izohlar

Zebrafish
~100,000 – 1,000,000
⚠️ Qisman
Suzish naqshlari, oddiy o‘rganish va reflekslar laboratoriyalarda takrorlangan. To‘liq idrok/his-tuyg‘ular mavjud emas.

Kemiruvchilar (sichqon)
~71 million
⚠️ Cheklangan
Labirint navigatsiyasi, asosiy qaror qabul qilish AI modellarida takrorlanadigan. Murakkab ijtimoiy/o‘rganish xatti-harakati to‘liq takrorlanmaydi.

Qurbaqalar
~16 million
⚠️ Cheklangan
Motor reflekslari simulyatsiya qilinishi mumkin; moslashuvchan xatti-harakat qisman tushunilgan.

Miqyos: 10⁶–10⁸ neyron
Texnologiya: Yuqori aniqlikdagi tasvirlash, optogenetika, AI simulyatsiyalari. Nanotexnologiyaga asoslangan neyron darajasidagi o‘qish/manipulyatsiya tadqiqot bosqichida.
To‘liq xatti-harakat takrorlashgacha yillar: 50+ yil realistik, agar nanotexnologiya va yuqori o‘lchamli neyron yozuvi tezroq rivojlanmasa.
4. Murakkab sut emizuvchilar – to‘liq takrorlash hozirda imkonsiz

Hayvon
Neyronlar
Holati
Izohlar

Itlar
~500 million
❌ Imkonsiz
Izolyatsiya qilingan vazifalarni (naqsh tanish, o‘rgatilgan xatti-harakatlar) AI va robototexnika bilan takrorlash mumkin. To‘liq idrok/his-tuyg‘ular erishib bo‘lmaydi.

Maymunlar
6–7 milliard
❌ Imkonsiz
Qisman xatti-harakat tadqiqotlari laboratoriyalarda mumkin; to‘liq takrorlash butun miya va sensor tizimini xaritalashni talab qiladi.

Odamlar
~86 milliard
❌ Imkonsiz
Haqiqiy emergent xatti-harakat, ong, xotira va ijodkorlik hali takrorlanmaydi.

Miqyos: 10⁸–10¹¹ neyron
Texnologiya: Har bir neyronni real vaqtda o‘qish/yozishga qodir faraziy nanotexnologiya; kvant hisoblash yuqori o‘lchamli simulyatsiyani tezlashtirishi mumkin.
Hatto qisman “to‘liq xatti-harakat takrorlash”gacha yillar: 100+ yil, ehtimol faqat ilg‘or nanotexnologiya va o‘ta yuqori o‘lchamli hisoblash bilan erishiladi.
5. Texnologiya omillari va talablari

Omil
Hozirgi imkoniyat
Kelajak potentsiali

Neyron xaritalash
Elektron mikroskopiya, optogenetika, connectomics (qisman)
Nanobotlar har bir sinapsni in vivo o‘qish uchun (~2040–2060)

Hisoblash
Superkompyuterlar, bulut klasterlari (~10¹⁵ FLOPS)
Ekzaskala (~10¹⁸ FLOPS) sut emizuvchilar miyasi uchun; zettaskala (~10²¹ FLOPS) odamlar uchun

Nano-sensorlar / aktuatorlar
Tadqiqot bosqichi
Murakkab hayvonlarning real vaqtda neyron darajasidagi takrorlanishi va yopiq tsikl simulyatsiyasiga imkon berishi mumkin

Saqlash
1–10 TB qurt/frukt pashshasi neyron ma’lumotlari uchun
~100 PB odam miqyosidagi connectome + dinamika uchun

6. Asosiy tushunchalar

Biz oddiy umurtqasizlarni bugun to‘liq takrorlay olamiz — C. elegans deyarli “hal qilingan”.
O‘rtacha hasharotlar uchun to‘liq neyron takrorlash 15–30 yilda hozirgi nevrologiya va AI tendentsiyalari bilan mumkin.
Kichik umurtqalilar asr o‘rtalarida qisman takrorlanishi mumkin.
Murakkab sut emizuvchilar va odamlar hozirgi texnologiyadan buyuklik tartibida ortda; to‘liq takrorlash nanotexnologiya, o‘ta yuqori hisoblash resurslari va o‘ta yuqori o‘lchamli simulyatsiyani talab qiladi — ehtimol bir asr uzoqda.
Emergent xatti-harakatlar chiziqli emas, balki eksponensial miqyosda o‘sadi: neyronlarni ikki baravar oshirish murakkablikni eksponensial ko‘paytiradi.

title: My Story.en
content:
My name is Ruhiddin Turdaliyev, born on 28 June 2003 in the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan. I grew up as a Kyrgyz native, bilingual in Uzbek, and gradually reached an English level around B2. My early education took place at local school No. 59 in the Fergana District, where I felt confident, even strong, compared to my classmates. But that confidence would be challenged soon.
After the 9th grade, I was accepted into the Academic Lyceum under TUIT Fergana branch, specializing in the technicians direction with a focus on math and physics. The moment I entered, I realized something painful: everything I knew was shallow compared to the competition-level students around me. They had deep foundations, while I was suddenly the one who knew nothing at all.
The first year was harsh. My results were the worst in the entire lyceum. At one point, the administration called my parent to the director’s office to warn that I would either improve immediately or be removed from the institution. I returned home only once a week, carrying the pressure of catching up to a world I had never imagined. Yet, in that difficult environment, I found loyal roommates and friends who stood with me, helped me understand subjects, and kept me from breaking under the weight.
Those two years (2019–2021) became a period of rebuilding myself from scratch. Day by day, topic by topic, I wrestled with math and physics until I almost reached the level of the best students in my class. By the end, I discovered that I loved physics more deeply than math. The lyceum awarded me a certificate as a “Technical Programmer,” a small reminder of how far I had climbed.
When the national exam came, I scored 152.25 out of 189 and submitted five choices for university:

Mathematics (NUU),
2–5. Mathematics & Informatics in various universities.

I chose the “Sirtqi” (part-time) format intentionally so I could study independently alongside university. I had wanted IT at TUIT, but fear of failure made me choose safer directions. Ironically, I did not expect to be accepted into my first choice at NUU in Pure Mathematics, yet that is where I landed, according to the rules that assign applicants to the highest successful option.
While studying in Tashkent, I spent my free time in Fergana continuing self-study. My parents supported me once again, buying me a laptop in December 2021 so I could learn IT seriously. In truth, my interests had long been drifting toward electronics, robotics, and automation, but these fields felt too young in Uzbekistan, with limited resources and weak education. So I began with something more accessible: web development.
I started with frontend. I learned HTML with heavy exhaustion, tried building a decent-looking website, only to feel that the time I spent had been wasted. Then I discovered CSS through Uzbek tutorials, practiced small pages, and slowly got better. But a realization struck: frontend felt shallow to me, too focused on design, not enough logic. I wanted depth, structure, reasoning. I wanted backend.
I began learning Java for its security, but I didn’t like the syntax and remembered seeing a more elegant language somewhere. So I turned to Python. I bought Python Basic and Python Advanced courses from PDP Academy for about $130. After completing them, I looked into the next modules, but the high cost and the one-year access limit discouraged me. I began searching for alternatives and found that the same-level Python content was freely available on YouTube through SariqDev.
That discovery shifted something in me. I realized many educational centers had turned learning into business. It became clear that without English, a person could not develop seriously. So I joined offline courses — not one, but nearly ten different learning centers — staying no more than 2.5 months at each because I was dissatisfied with progress, environment, or cost. No center gave me the energy, focus, or pressure that my lyceum days had given me. I understood that true results were coming from my own attempts, not from institutions.
That realization pushed me toward full self-study. My plan became simple: learn English well enough to open the gates to all other knowledge. Those months felt like wandering — like a lost ant trying to find its destiny — filled with valuable experiences that came at the cost of precious time.
During this period, I learned Django and backend development, but another issue arose: backend work was invisible. Even my parents could not see what I was doing, and IT was something completely new in the countryside. That made me decide to become a full-stack developer. I learned JavaScript, React, Redux, and even touched mobile development through React Native and Expo. I worked intensely, but my English remained a bottleneck.
In 2024, I finally reached the level where I could study English-language resources directly. Time then became my tightest constraint. Around this period, I also began listening to English Islamic lectures, especially from Nouman Ali Khan. This strengthened my comprehension, and it felt natural because Islam was already familiar to me. Along with that, I held a personal principle: to learn languages without adopting the behaviors or moral patterns of their cultures, so that I would not lose my own identity in the process.
In November 2024, I joined Velo Ijara, a small bike rental company in Tashkent, not just as a practical trainee but as the lead developer within the trainee framework. I worked there for eight months, handling the technical side while gaining real-world experience in a small but active environment.
Recently, I revisited electronics through YouTube lessons. Suddenly, the advanced physics theories I had learned in the lyceum connected with the physical devices I had never seen closely before. That combination gave me new hope of returning to this field someday.
I believe that if God permits, I can learn and do anything. But I also know my nature: I dive deeply into new subjects, absorb them fully, and then often feel overwhelmed by the amount of work needed to bring the ideas to life. Time, budget, and resources intimidate me. I do not think I will feel fulfilled working only as a regular employee; I am drawn toward craft, design, and invention. The conditions around me may not support these ambitions, but I still care about them. I share my ideas and paths not for fame, but because I want to see those ideas come alive in the real world, even if through someone else’s hands.
